item.title: Report E-2023110057
item.description:
Report E-2023110057

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-07T18:15:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-24
  • City: TUNNEL HILL
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 24, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1263 was damaged during loading and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Marion Environmental (ME) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail and placed it in one (1) 30-gallon drum for transport to the local RLC terminal to be moved to the facilities waste consolidation area. ME personnel utilized absorbent pads to remove free product from the trailer floor and deployed granular absorbents to collect any residual product. All paint impacted material was collected in one (1) poly trash bag and ME took possession of the waste.

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1760 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock surface. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the damaged drum and placed in in one (1) 85-gallon over pack. FCE personnel utilized hand tools to collect all granular absorbents applied by RLC. All ammonium hydroxide impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and both drums were added to RLC waste stream for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023110034
item.description:
Report E-2023110034

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-07T18:15:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-19
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, ten (10) 5-gallon bladders of UN3267 were punctured by a forklift and released approximately seven (7) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. EWI personnel neutralized and collected the released product with citric acid, and they repeated this process until no corrosive liquid remained and the surface had a neutral pH. Crews cut-up the impacted pallet with hand tools. All neutralized product, the cut-up pallet, the ten (10) damaged bladders, and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums that were staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of printing ink was impacted by a skid and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3/OMI (E3) to remediate the impacted site. . E3 personnel deployed granular absorbents to the printing ink-impacted floor and swept them in with hand tools. They cut up the impacted pallet and all spent absorbents and waste were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 85-gallon over pack for transport and disposal.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, one (1) one-gallon pail of UN2922 was crushed during transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior and adjacent freight. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ancon Services (AS) to remediate the impacted site. AS personnel removed all pallets from the freight and began collecting the damaged pails in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew deployed absorbents and worked them in using hand tools. AS placed the absorbents in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2023110010
item.description:
Report E-2023110010

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-31
  • City: SAN ANTONIO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSX experienced a UN2810 Durez 04347A Liquid One Step Phenolic Resin release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. All impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were containerized into a 5-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: It was reported that due to a weeping weld 1 cup of material has been released onto the concrete floor, a contractor was required for the transfer of the product. It was determined that the tote could not be repaired and the product will need to be transferred. There was 350 Gallons of product in the leaking tote. All impacted surfaces were wiped down with water and the 1 cup of material released was absorbed into pads and containerized. The material remaining in the damaged tote was transferred to two new totes and they will continue to the destination. Terminal staff advised that the leaking steel tote will be returned to the shipper. (1) 5G DF - Impacted pads was created for waste and was left for the terminal to manage.

  • City: TOMAH
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of UN3082 "Elco 105" was released to a 4’ x 4’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a puncture caused by other freight. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one for shipment to continue on. The impacted area was cleaned with absorbents. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into a cubic yard box and a 30-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100912
item.description:
Report E-2023100912

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-06T09:12:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-19
  • City: MATTESON
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN2014 was damaged in transit and released approximately 275-gallons of product to the trailer floor and concrete beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized hand tools to collect and containerize all free-standing product and previously deployed absorbents from the trailer floor into five (5) 55-gallon open top drums. HCE personnel utilized a forklift to perform a gravity transfer of the remaining UN2014 in the tote into one (1) additional 55-gallon open top drum. All UN2014-impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal. The impacted wood pallets were staged on site along with the seven (7) previously generated 55-gallon drums for further management.

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-18
  • City: MONTEBELLO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 18, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of printing ink was punctured while in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental (GE) to remediate the impacted site. GE personnel deployed granular absorbent to the trailer floor and worked them in with hand tools, utilizing a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any residual product. The crew collected and containerized the damaged 55-gallon drum in one (1) 65-gallon overpack drum. All printing ink impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and RLC personnel took possession of the waste.

  • Description: It was reported a pallet of 8 metal drums arrived at the facility containing Hazardous Phenol Solution, UN2821, of which 2 of the drums were visibly damaged. The drums were corroded, with the paint being clearly corroded and reaching into the layer of metal. The corrosion has caused the caps to unseal from the container and an odor, although not strong, was emanating from the damaged drums. It was confirmed 10oz spilled onto the tops of 2 of the drums. Two DM of waste were created, 2-85 gal overpack containing an impacted drum, both were left staged onsite for the terminal to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100865
item.description:
Report E-2023100865

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-01T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-16
  • City: MIAMI
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: LAN CARGO S.A.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 16, 2023, Aerolinahs Brasileiras S.A.’s (DBA LATAM Cargo Brasil, formerly TAM Cargo) flight 8473 departed from Miami International Airport. Approximately 30 minutes after takeoff, the flight returned to Miami International Airport due to the detection of a strong chemical smell from the Main Deck. 2. Cargo Area Inspection: Upon the flight's return to Miami International Airport, the Miami Dade Fire Department was called to investigate the situation. They requested that the Main Deck be opened to ventilate the area and check for any potential leakage of dangerous goods. 3. Identification of the Chemical: During the inspection, a pallet in position 2R was identified to contain RFL UN1089 Acetaldehyde. This pallet was promptly removed from its position for further examination. It was later determined that there was no spill of the substance either on the pallet or on the floor of the aircraft. 4. Safety Measures and Gas Dissipation: Following the removal of the pallet, the Miami Dade Fire Department allowed the aircraft to remain open for approximately 30 minutes to ensure proper ventilation and to monitor the situation. After this time, the Fire Department’s team conducted a cargo inspection and, having found no further issues, cleared the plane for operation. The pallet involved in the incident was isolated for an additional 40 minutes to allow any lingering gases to dissipate, making it safe for handling. 5. Preliminary Investigation Findings: During the preliminary investigation, it was confirmed that all procedures for handling dangerous goods were followed correctly. While there may have been a partial smell of non-toxic gas, it was determined that the packaging containing the Acetaldehyde was not damaged, and therefore, it did not pose a safety risk.

  • Description: PACKAGE WAS BROUGHT TO THE DMP AROUND 1:30 AM, FROM DOOR 33 ON THE UNLOAD, BY THE RESPONDER. IN THE DMP, PACKAGE WAS OPENED AND FOUND TO CONTAIN, THREE, 1 GALLON PLASTIC BOTTLES OF ALPHA 90 IA FLUX, BEING SHIPPED AS A CORROSIVE HAZ-MAT PACKAGE, (UN3284, CORROSIVE LIQUID, ACIDIC, INORGANIC, N.O.S. (HYDROCHLORIC ACID, ZINC CHLORIDE), 8, II, 1 FIBERBOARD BOX X3 GALLONS). THE CAPS ON TWO OF THE THREE BOTTLES, WHERE LOOSE, WHICH ALLOWED A LARGE AMOUNT OF THE ACID TO LEAK FROM BOTH BOTTLES WITH LOOSE CAPS. ALL PRODUCT WAS PROCESSED THROUGH THE DMP, ALONG WITH CARBOARD FROM SEVERAL OTHER BOXES WHICH WHERE AROUND THE LEAKING PACKAGE.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: FRA was inspecting cars a spotted residue on the side of CBTX 735329 opened the combination housing. Inside the housing found the liquid valve to be seeping at the base of the valve where it threads into the tank car. . Marathon Petroleum sent out there emergency responder SRS to remove the valve. Once the valve had been removed and visually inspected lack of thread sealant was deemed the reason why the valve was leaking. CBTX 735329 was then set out on the Rip track so it can have a certified leak test preformed.

UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TWO X 5.1 OZ BOTTLES OF PAUL MITCHELL SUPER SKINNY SERUM. BOTH WERE LEAKING FROM LOOSE CLOSURES.

item.title: Report E-2023100408
item.description:
Report E-2023100408

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-04T06:23:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-30
  • City: Selma
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX Transportation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/30/23, at 2104, personnel in the CSXT Clifton Forge yard reported NATX400224, a loaded tank car of Anhydrous Ammonia, was suspected to leaking. The car was isolated and the shipper, Advansix, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2023-10-01-00001). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, as well as a CSXT Manager of Hazardous Materials, were dispatched to the scene and found product leaking through the pressure relief valve. CSX and contractor personnel contained the release with application of an emergency capping kit until such time that the contents of the leaking car were transloaded into tank car NATX400291. Additionally, response personnel utilized a highway transport truck to unload approximately 4,000 liquid gallons of product that could not be safely loaded into the NATX 400291 due to volumetric outage constraints. Because the leaking car was not equipped with a gauging device, response personnel were unable to determine the specific reason why the identified calf car could not accept the entire load; however, it is suspected that the NATX 400224 was originally overloaded prior to the pressure relief device failure. Upon completion of the product transload, response personnel purged the leaking car to clean/empty status. All issues identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Christian Beale 804-731-8124). While the car was suspected to be overloaded, the pressure relief device continued to leak for the duration of the unloading process- even at acceptable load volume and pressure. Because of the this, the pressure relief device was identified as non-conforming and an AAR form QA 7.1 was filed.

item.title: Report X-2023090198
item.description:
Report X-2023090198

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-04T06:23:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-09
  • City: MEMPHIS
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/9/2023 at approximately 1430, Dangerous Good Administration received a call from Employee 658069 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting a spill incident, involving an undeclared corrosive liquid. The shipment consists of 1 fiberboard box conaining six 64oz bottles of Clobber drain cleaner. Per an online safety data safety, the shipment contained concentrated sulfuric acid and is classifed as UN 1830. Three of the bottles spilled from the package resulting in sizable spill and contaminating an estimated 30 packages. A vendor was called in the contain the spill. The affected shipments have been handles accrodingly. Further investigation revealed the spilled package was not declared as dangerous goods, in compliance with IATA Regulations. The shipment is places in a salvage drum and is being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Hazmat was found at unload door 24 on 9/25/23 during the preload sort at about 3 AM, package was leaking contents from the bottom of the package onto the floor. Quality Assurance was notified and immediately cleaned up the spill. DescribePack: External inspection showed that liquid was protruding from the fiberboard box onto the floor and continued to leak after being placed in a hazardous tote. Internal inspection showed that the plastic bag of isopropyl alcohol (UN1219) was contained in a cardboard box and the box was leaking from the bottom of the package, not the lid/closure. Therefore, the plastic bag was punctured and leaking out product. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Proper PPE equipment was used to contain the spill by notifying Quality Assurance immediately. Absorbency Pads, a hazardous tote, and gloves were properly used.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found leaking and also emitting a visible gas on door 65 in load 6 of the RORS Unload. Package was taken by QA personnel out of the load area and was isolated from the rest of the staff. Package had a powerful odor, vapor and liquid leaking out of it. Package had Fully Regulated HazMat labeling Corrosive) and was determined to be a HazMat. The package was put in a plastic bin to prevent it from melting through the metal/cardboard. The item was also put next to a vent in the HazMat Cage to prevent inhalation. DescribePack: 1 of the 4 plastic bottles of Hydrochloric Acid had a loose cap, which allowed for the acid to leak out, this caused a chemical reaction that destroyed the box, and also rusted the metal plate on door 65 that it was placed on. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Package was taken to the HazMat Cage for isolation and processing.

  • Description: During the morning sort at our ramp location in Romulus MI, a plastic Jerrican was punctured containing UN 3264, Corrosive liquid, acidic, inorganic, n.o.s (Aluminum Hydroxychloride) at the bottom of the piece. It was seen that during the ULD loading process, the jerrican was placed on an unseen protruding rivet causing the puncture and allowing for an estimated 236 mL to escape. No other packages were compromised because of this leak. The jerrican was contained in a salvage drum to prevent further leakage. Consignee was contacted to inform customer of the damaged package and inquire for disposition.

It appears the closure failed on the inner container, resulting in spillage. Further investigation revealing that rthe contents that spilled appears to be paint, as the inner container is marked as "Coffee Bean Stain". The package is not marked, labeled, or prepared as dangerous goods shipment. The shipment has been placed in a salvage drum and being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

item.title: Report X-2023081356
item.description:
Report X-2023081356

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-03T00:35:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-14
  • City: MCCOMB
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 14, CN Transportation crews observed liquid dripping down the sides on UTLX 125075. The railcar was isolated and all required notifications were made. CN response contractor responded to the site. Upon approaching the railcar, liquid was observed streaming down the sides of the railcar and pooling on the ground below the railcar. Under closer inspection, liquid was observed coming from the liquid eduction line. Attempts were made to tighten the cap and were unsuccessful. The pressure was relieved which stopped the leak. The liquid eduction cap was again attempted to be tightened again; 7 additional turns were achieved. The cap was removed to check if a gasket was installed. No gasket was observed. A gasket was installed in the liquid eduction cap and teflon tape was applied to the threads. The liquid eduction cap was properly installed. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated. The railcar was released onto destination.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-31
  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ODOT Hazmat Inspector C. Kuenzi identified the SHQX 50612 as leaking vapor in the protective housing during an inspection at the PTRC - Lakeyard. The car was isolated by PTRC employees and BNSF dispatched contract responders to inspect the car. The responders found the vapor valve plug to be less than tool tight, easily moved by hand and the valve to be partially open. The valve was fully closed and the leak was mitigated. The plug was removed, inspected and had teflon tape applied. The car was fully secured and inspected, then released back into transportation. All released LPG dissipated and no clean up was necessary. Estimated release volumes are only based upon a best estimate as observed by responders.
